snippet.textDisplay:
I remember accidentally scratching up my copy of the original Wild Arms game, and searching all over about a 40 mile radius for the original. KB Toys had this game, so I grudgingly gave it a shot.

I love it, still play it to this day, and actually prefer it over the original. <3
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I once got stuck on this game for a looooong time (several years) and stopped playing. I was near the end of the 2nd disc. A few months ago I found it and played it after years of not using my old PS1, and finally finished it. After the credits, the console blacked out and stopped working. When I went to repair it, I was told the console was unusable since its chips had already been completely burnt for at least a month before.

Wild Arms 2 is just THAT good.
snippet.textOriginal:

When I went to repair it, I was told the console was unusable since its chips had already been completely burnt for at least a month before.

Wild Arms 2 is just THAT good.

snippet.textDisplay: I love these games' music. They sound so Japanese while still having a really strong Wild West feel to them. The music is already great on its own but when put together with games with this kind of setting, it gets really immersive.

snippet.textDisplay: I find some of the best music and games r the older ones, they made them for people who had more patience. Nowadays theres not much story line to most of them.

snippet.textDisplay:
For me it went: WA3, WA4, Alter code F, WA5.

I'd recommend starting with WA3 too, since it's got the traditional battle system. WA4 and 5 have the HEX battle system, which is good too.
snippet.textOriginal:
For me it went: WA3, WA4, Alter code F, WA5.

I'd recommend starting with WA3 too, since it's got the traditional battle system. WA4 and 5 have the HEX battle system, which is good too.

snippet.textDisplay: That's a very tough question! It really depends on your level of patience. I'd say the easy answer would be to simply play them in order. It might sound stupid, but you might want to watch a video or two of a typical WA battle and see if you could go through that, it's very old school. If not, then I'd recommend WA3 as your first game in the series and go from there if you like it.
snippet.textOriginal: That's a very tough question! It really depends on your level of patience. I'd say the easy answer would be to simply play them in order. It might sound stupid, but you might want to watch a video or two of a typical WA battle and see if you could go through that, it's very old school. If not, then I'd recommend WA3 as your first game in the series and go from there if you like it.

snippet.textDisplay:
Of course you hear a resemblance; it's the same composer, the music is coming from the same brain, so there's bound to be some "common elements" either melodically, rhytmically or harmonically (??), or just in the instruments used (they're similar in all games on these older systems like PS)!

I don't know why some dum-dums thumbed you down; I'm giving you 2 thumbs up :)
snippet.textOriginal:
Of course you hear a resemblance; it's the same composer, the music is coming from the same brain, so there's bound to be some "common elements" either melodically, rhytmically or harmonically (??), or just in the instruments used (they're similar in all games on these older systems like PS)!

I don't know why some dum-dums thumbed you down; I'm giving you 2 thumbs up :)

snippet.textDisplay: A lot of people I know didn't really enjoy this game all so much as the story didn't seem to connect at any point in any way. It was almost as if like 4 or 5 people wrote ideas down and they put them all together without actually trying to link them. Like, what ever happened to Liz and Ard? What do the robots have to do with anything? Either way I loved the game and the music is totally radical. The japanese intros were super cool too.
snippet.textOriginal: A lot of people I know didn't really enjoy this game all so much as the story didn't seem to connect at any point in any way. It was almost as if like 4 or 5 people wrote ideas down and they put them all together without actually trying to link them. Like, what ever happened to Liz and Ard? What do the robots have to do with anything? Either way I loved the game and the music is totally radical. The japanese intros were super cool too.

snippet.textDisplay: Wild Arms 2 had one of the most catchy intro songs in any series.  This field theme is also good but the opening song is still burned into my brain and I haven't played the game in years.
snippet.textOriginal: Wild Arms 2 had one of the most catchy intro songs in any series.  This field theme is also good but the opening song is still burned into my brain and I haven't played the game in years.

snippet.textDisplay: I see. Well hey, if you hear a resemblance, it's all that matters in the end!

snippet.textDisplay: Haha, I can see that!

snippet.textDisplay: Hmmm I'll be honest with you, I don't hear any ressemblance! Maybe it's the whistle, but then again the first game uses something more like a flute (or a synth whistle). It's probably just something to do with the way Michiko Naruke builds her tracks, but then again the first game's overworld theme is basically "Ecstasy of Gold v2.0". :P
snippet.textOriginal: Hmmm I'll be honest with you, I don't hear any ressemblance! Maybe it's the whistle, but then again the first game uses something more like a flute (or a synth whistle). It's probably just something to do with the way Michiko Naruke builds her tracks, but then again the first game's overworld theme is basically "Ecstasy of Gold v2.0". :P
